awd_titl_txt: SHF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Building Critical Systems with Verifiable Properties Using Gate Level Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Computer performance has doubled many times over during the past 40 years, but the very techniques used to achieve these performance gains have made it increasingly difficult to build systems that are provably safe, secure, or reliable. This fact significantly impedes progress in the development of our most safety-critical embedded systems such as those found in medical, avionic, automotive, and military systems.  A transformation in the way that these systems are created is needed, one that uses new hardware design techniques, computer architectures, and programming languages to create classes of hardware/software systems with formal and provable safety properties that are verifiable all the way down to the implementation level of bits and logic gates.

This research will change the way that hardware and embedded systems designers approach the problem of provable properties, enabling them to directly control and analyze the system at the lowest level and to statically determine if their designs are in compliance with a given policy.  For example, if a system must be real-time this property can be verifiable for a full system, from gates to software, by ensuring that the architecture design carefully manages interference through a set of new hardware primitives, software designed to exploit these new primitives, specialized hardware analysis tools, and new design languages.  To ensure this technology will have impact beyond academia the PIs are making these new technologies available and accessible through easy to use tools, continuing to include undergraduates at all levels of research to help train a new generation of engineers capable of designing safety-critical systems, and integrating concepts from information assurance into their extensive outreach activities.  Over the long term this research will help create the skills and tools that embedded system engineers need to evaluate the trustworthiness of their systems, and it will ease the development of those critical systems on which we all depend on for our safety and livelihood.

por.por_cntn:
Computing plays a core role of vast number of safety critical and high assurance systems including medical devices, avionics, automobiles, military systems, power grid, and communication infrastructures. These systems can consist of millions of lines of software code running on a hardware chip composed of billions of transistors. The level of complexity is immense, which makes it difficult, perhaps impossible to insure that these computer systems are adhering to their specifications, let alone that they are immune to safety flaws or security holes. Thus, it is paramount that we develop advanced techniques to aid in the design, development, and analysis of safe and secure computing systems. 

The intellectual merits of this project explored design techniques that enable computer system developers to understand the safety and security of the system under development. This project developed novel hardware architectures that enforced separation and isolation of critical tasks; it created a general design methodology for static and dynamic verification of security properties; and it provided guarantees that computer systems adhered to safety properties such as determinism, fault-tolerance, and real-time guarantees.

The broader impacts of this project focused on training the next generation of computer scientists and engineers in the design of safe and secure hardware and computing systems. The project provided direct education of post-doctoral researchers, graduate students, undergraduate students, and high school students (through summer programs). Additionally, the technology developed in this project is being commercialized by Tortuga Logic. Tortuga Logic creates tools that analyze the security of computing systems, such as those in medical devices, communication devices, and automobiles. Tortuga Logic is licensing two patents from the University of California that were submitted as a direct result of the research in this project.
